remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Hello, thank you for coming in today. I understand you’ve been experiencing nausea, vomiting, and right lower quadrant abdominal pain since last night. Can you describe if your abdominal pain has changed in intensity or location since it began?

Um, yes, thank you, doctor. The main thing that brought me in is this right lower quadrant abdominal pain—it’s been pretty uncomfortable since last night. I’m not sure if it’s gotten worse, but it just hasn’t let up, and I’m feeling pretty miserable.

Thank you for sharing that—persistent abdominal pain can be very distressing. In addition to the pain, can you tell me more about your nausea and vomiting—specifically, how often you’ve been experiencing these symptoms and whether you’ve noticed any blood or unusual color in your vomit?

remedi_labels.value: Thank you for sharing that—persistent abdominal pain can be very distressing.
how often you’ve been experiencing these symptoms
whether you’ve noticed any blood or unusual color in your vomit

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um… the nausea and vomiting have been happening on and off since last night. I think I’ve thrown up a few times—maybe three? I’m not sure if there was blood, but it did look kind of dark, almost like coffee grounds. Also, I should mention, I’ve had this kind of chronic abdominal pain after meals for a while now, but this feels different—more intense, I guess.

remedi_labels.value: vomit looked dark, almost like coffee grounds
abdominal pain more intense than usual

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Let me think… Actually, I haven’t really noticed any black or tarry stools, but it’s a little hard for me to tell sometimes because of my ostomy. I do have chronic abdominal pain, usually after meals, but this pain feels more like acute on chronic abdominal pain—just sharper and more persistent than usual. Should I be worried about the coffee-ground emesis?

remedi_labels.value: chronic abdominal pain, usually after meals
acute on chronic abdominal pain—sharper and more persistent than usual

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be anxious—assessing coffee-ground material in your vomit can be alarming, and it’s important we take it seriously. You mentioned having a fever as well; have you experienced any shaking chills or noticed your temperature staying elevated for more than 24 hours?

remedi_labels.value: temperature staying elevated for more than 24 hours

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Um, yes, actually, I did have some shaking chills last night, and my temperature went up pretty high—I think it was around 103, maybe a little over. It’s been up there for more than a day now, on and off. I’m just feeling really uncomfortable and kind of weak. Is that something I should be really concerned about?

remedi_labels.value: Is that something I should be really concerned about?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried—persistent high fevers and shaking chills are concerning symptoms and it’s important we address them promptly. During your clinical assessment, did you notice any worsening of your abdominal tenderness or any new areas of pain when your fever was at its highest?

Well, um… now that you mention it, I think the abdominal tenderness did get worse when my fever was at its highest. The pain seemed to spread out a bit—like, it wasn’t just in the right lower quadrant anymore, but more diffuse across my belly. I haven’t really noticed any new pain in my back, but the abdominal pain definitely got more intense. I’m just worried because it’s not getting better, and actually feels like it’s getting worse. Should I be concerned about this worsening abdominal pain?

remedi_labels.value: pain spreading from right lower quadrant to diffuse across abdomen

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried about your worsening abdominal pain, especially with persistent high fevers and diffuse tenderness. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any symptoms such as shortness of breath, chest discomfort, or lightheadedness along with your abdominal pain and fever?

Actually, yes, now that you mention it—I have felt a bit lightheaded, especially when I try to stand up. I don’t think I’ve had real chest discomfort, but maybe just a little fluttering feeling, which I guess could be from my atrial fibrillation? And I have noticed some shortness of breath, but I thought maybe that was just from feeling so weak and uncomfortable with all these symptoms.

The nausea and vomiting are still pretty bad, and the coffee-ground emesis really scared me. I’m just not sure what’s going on, and I’m worried because nothing seems to be getting better. Is there something serious happening?

I can understand why you’d be anxious, especially with persistent symptoms and high fevers. During your clinical assessment, have you noticed any signs of rigidity or guarding in your abdomen when it’s examined, or has the tenderness remained mostly mild and diffuse?

Well, um, when the nurse pressed on my abdomen earlier, I definitely felt a lot of tenderness—it was pretty diffuse, not just in one spot. I don’t know if it was true rigidity or guarding, but I did tense up a bit because it hurt. The pain just seems to be everywhere now, not just the right lower quadrant. And my fever really spiked last night—I saw it go up to 103.6. 

I’m just feeling so uncomfortable and honestly a little scared. Is this kind of diffuse abdominal tenderness with a high fever something that could mean an infection or something serious? I just want to know what’s going on and get some relief.

I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—persistent high fever and diffuse abdominal tenderness are definitely concerning symptoms. During your assessment, have you experienced any signs of abdominal distension, or have you noticed any changes in your ostomy output, such as decreased volume or unusual color?

remedi_labels.value: decreased volume or unusual color of ostomy output

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Let me think… Actually, I have noticed some abdominal distension—my belly feels a bit more bloated than usual. As for my ostomy output, it seems like the volume has gone down, and the color looks a little darker than normal. I’m not sure if that’s important, but it’s definitely different from what I usually see.

Also, I’ve been feeling really dry—like my mouth and lips are just parched. The nurse mentioned my mucous membranes were dry, and I think my heart’s been racing too; they said I was tachycardic. I just feel so uncomfortable and weak, and honestly, I’m worried about what all these symptoms together might mean. Is there something serious going on? What should I expect next?

I can understand why you’d be worried—persistent high fever, diffuse abdominal tenderness, abdominal distension, and decreased ostomy output are all concerning symptoms that suggest a potentially serious underlying condition, such as infection or inflammation in the abdomen. Based on your medical history and current symptoms, I’d like to ask: have you noticed any signs of confusion, difficulty staying awake, or changes in your mental status during this episode?

Well, um… now that you mention it, I have felt a little more confused than usual at times—like, sometimes I just feel kind of foggy or it’s hard to concentrate. I haven’t actually fallen asleep unexpectedly, but I do feel really tired and sort of out of it. I’m not sure if that’s from the fever or just everything going on.

Also, I overheard the nurse mention my blood pressure was low, so I guess that means I’m hypotensive? And they said my breathing was faster than normal—tachypnea, I think? I just feel really uncomfortable, weak, and honestly a bit scared because these symptoms all seem to be piling up. Is this something that could get worse quickly? What should I expect in terms of treatment or next steps?

I can understand why you’d be worried—your symptoms of high fever, diffuse abdominal tenderness, abdominal distension, decreased ostomy output, and episodes of confusion are all concerning and suggest a potentially serious abdominal infection or sepsis. Based on your medical history and current symptoms, during your examination did anyone note any signs of peritoneal irritation, such as rebound tenderness or involuntary guarding, which could indicate peritonitis?

remedi_labels.value: potentially serious abdominal infection or sepsis
signs of peritoneal irritation such as rebound tenderness or involuntary guarding

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Well, um… I think when they pressed on my belly earlier, it definitely hurt more when they let go—so maybe that’s rebound tenderness? I did tense up a bit too, but I’m not sure if that counts as involuntary guarding. Everything just feels so sore and sensitive right now.

Also, I overheard someone mention something about bilateral basilar crackles and perihilar airspace opacities on my chest imaging. Does that mean there’s something going on with my lungs too? I’m just feeling really overwhelmed with all these symptoms—abdominal pain, fever, confusion, and now possibly something in my lungs. Is this all connected? What should I expect next? I just want to feel better.

remedi_labels.value: bilateral basilar crackles and perihilar airspace opacities on chest imaging

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Thank you for sharing these details—it’s understandable to feel overwhelmed with multiple symptoms occurring at once. Based on your description, you are experiencing persistent high fever, diffuse abdominal tenderness with possible rebound, decreased ostomy output, confusion, and now findings on chest imaging suggesting possible pneumonia or aspiration. To help guide my assessment, have you noticed any new or worsening cough, sputum production, or difficulty breathing in addition to your abdominal symptoms?

remedi_labels.value: diffuse abdominal tenderness with possible rebound
findings on chest imaging suggesting possible pneumonia or aspiration

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Well, um… yes, actually, I have noticed some new symptoms with my breathing. I’ve been a bit more short of breath than usual, and I’ve had a cough that started just a day or two ago. It’s not a really strong cough, but sometimes I bring up a little sputum—it looks kind of yellowish. Breathing just feels a bit harder, especially when I’m lying down.

And about the fever—I’ve had shaking chills and my temperature has been over 102 degrees for more than a day now. None of this seems to be getting better after 48 hours; if anything, it feels like symptoms are getting worse. The abdominal pain is still really bad, and now with the confusion and all these new symptoms, I’m just really uncomfortable and worried.

Is it possible that all of this—my abdominal symptoms and now the findings on my chest imaging—could be connected? Should I be worried about sepsis or something serious like that? What can you do to help me feel better?

remedi_labels.value: connection between abdominal symptoms and chest imaging findings
possibility of sepsis or something serious
what can be done to help feel better

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
I can understand why you’d be anxious—experiencing persistent abdominal pain, high fever, confusion, and now respiratory symptoms can be very overwhelming. Based on your symptoms, examination findings, and imaging clinical findings, there is a concern for a serious infection such as sepsis, possibly originating from your abdomen and potentially involving your lungs as well. At this point, it’s important that we continue close monitoring, provide intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and supportive care to stabilize your condition.

To further guide your treatment, have you had any recent blood cultures or imaging studies (such as a CT scan of the abdomen) performed to help identify the source of infection?

Thank you for explaining everything so clearly, doctor. Um, as far as I know, I had some blood drawn earlier today, and they mentioned something about blood cultures, but I’m not sure if the results are back yet. I haven’t had a CT scan of my abdomen during this visit—just some X-rays and chest imaging, I think. Would a CT scan help figure out what’s going on?

Also, I wanted to mention—I’ve been vomiting a lot, and sometimes I can’t even keep my medications down. I’m worried because I know some of them are really important, like my Coumadin and antibiotics. And actually, these symptoms seem to come back even after I finish treatment, which is frustrating.

I’m just feeling really uncomfortable and anxious right now. Is there anything else you can do to help with the nausea or the pain while we wait for more results? And should I be worried about symptoms getting worse before they get better?

no CT scan of abdomen during this visit
Would a CT scan help figure out what’s going on?

Is there anything else you can do to help with the nausea or the pain while we wait for more results?

While we await your blood culture clinical findings, have you experienced any new or worsening symptoms such as increased confusion, decreased urine output, or difficulty breathing since your last examination?

While we await the clinical findings of your blood cultures and arrange for abdominal imaging such as a CT scan to further evaluate the source of infection, I recommend continuing intravenous fluids, antibiotics, antiemetics, and supportive care; if your symptoms worsen or you notice any new neurological changes, please notify the medical team immediately.
